elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A one-dimensional coordination polymer, [CuMoO4(N2C12H8)]⋅H2O, was utilized as heterogeneous catalyst for the epoxidation of some olefins and allylic alcohols.     

Highlights

   ⋅ A copper molybdate coordination polymer has been synthesized.   ⋅ The coordination polymer was used as an epoxidation catalyst.   ⋅ The catalyst showed good activity and selectivity in the epoxidation reactions.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0040">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">A copper molybdate coordination polymer has been synthesized.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">The coordination polymer was used as an epoxidation catalyst.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">The catalyst showed good activity and selectivity in the epoxidation reactions.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st015">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">Through exploitation of hydrothermal synthesis, a mixture of crystals containing blue [CuMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and yellow ([Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>Cl(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>(1,10-phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]) (4,4′-bipy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-bipyridine and 1,10-phen<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,10-phenanthroline) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) were obtained. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a new 1-D coordination polymer while compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a known metal–organic framework. The obtained crystals have been further characterized by means of powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), FT-IR and inductive coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). The catalytic properties of the prepared mixture were investigated in the epoxidation of some olefins and allylic alcohols using <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) or cumene hydroperoxide (CHP) as oxidants. It was found that the crystals could serve as an active and selective catalyst for the epoxidation of the olefins and allylic alcohols. The catalyst can be recovered easily and reused in the reaction without considerable decrease in activity or selectivity. Moreover, the influence of the type of oxidant and solvent on the conversion of the olefins was studied.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
A copper molybdate coordination polymer has been synthesized.

The coordination polymer was used as an epoxidation catalyst.

The catalyst showed good activity and selectivity in the epoxidation reactions.

Abstract

Through exploitation of hydrothermal synthesis, a mixture of crystals containing blue [CuMoO4(N2C12H8)]⋅H2O (1) and yellow ([Cu3 ICl(4,4'-bipy)4][CuII(1,10-phen)2Mo8O26]) (4,4'-bipy=4,4'-bipyridine and 1,10-phen=1,10-phenanthroline) (2) were obtained. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound 1 is a new 1-D coordination polymer while compound 2 is a known metal-organic framework. The obtained crystals have been further characterized by means of powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), FT-IR and inductive coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). The catalytic properties of the prepared mixture were investigated in the epoxidation of some olefins and allylic alcohols using tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) or cumene hydroperoxide (CHP) as oxidants. It was found that the crystals could serve as an active and selective catalyst for the epoxidation of the olefins and allylic alcohols. The catalyst can be recovered easily and reused in the reaction without considerable decrease in activity or selectivity. Moreover, the influence of the type of oxidant and solvent on the conversion of the olefins was studied.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st025">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The synthesis, design and characterization of coordination polymers, based on the assembly of metal ions and functional organic ligands, have been rapidly developed owing to their special physical properties and potential applications in functional materials, for molecular adsorption, and ion exchange . Besides these applications, coordination polymers have emerged as catalysts for epoxidation of olefins .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The synthesis, design and characterization of coordination polymers, based on the assembly of metal ions and functional organic ligands, have been rapidly developed owing to their special physical properties and potential applications in functional materials, for molecular adsorption, and ion exchange . Besides these applications, coordination polymers have emerged as catalysts for epoxidation of olefins .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">In the area of catalysis, epoxidation of olefins is important in organic synthesis since epoxides are synthetic intermediates widely utilized for the manufacturing of chemicals such as surfactants, unsaturated resins, paints and other useful substances .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the area of catalysis, epoxidation of olefins is important in organic synthesis since epoxides are synthetic intermediates widely utilized for the manufacturing of chemicals such as surfactants, unsaturated resins, paints and other useful substances .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">A lot of research is directed to the heterogeneous catalytic processes owing to easier work-up and better recyclability and stability of the heterogeneous catalysts. A number of approaches have been developed for heterogenization of homogeneous catalysts using various supports such as silica , carbon , polymers , metal–organic frameworks  and metal oxide nanoparticles  or performing the reactions in unconventional media such as ionic liquids .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A lot of research is directed to the heterogeneous catalytic processes owing to easier work-up and better recyclability and stability of the heterogeneous catalysts. A number of approaches have been developed for heterogenization of homogeneous catalysts using various supports such as silica , carbon , polymers , metal-organic frameworks  and metal oxide nanoparticles  or performing the reactions in unconventional media such as ionic liquids .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Utilization of inorganic–organic hybrid materials and coordination polymers as self-supported catalysts is another development in this regard. Depending on the coordination geometry of the metals and the bonding preference of donating atoms as well as the geometry of organic linkers, coordination polymers with one, two or three dimensions can be constructed. These metal organic assemblies formed via coordinate bonds, hydrogen bonds and aromatic <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> interactions can be insoluble in the conventional reaction media and can be utilized as heterogeneous catalysts. Coordination polymers with extended structures do not suffer from negative effects of some pre-synthesized supports such as random anchoring, reduced catalytic activity and/or selectivity of catalysts due to poor accessibility, or disturbed geometry of active sites in the solid supports . Inorganic–organic hybrids and coordination polymers such as [{Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}(tptz){Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>Cl(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)}]·0.25H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (tptz<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,4,6-tris(2-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine),  [Cu(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>btec)(bipy)]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>btec<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid) , {[Ni(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)][γ-Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]·0.5 H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,4-bis (1,2,4-triazol-yi)butane) , and [MoO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dipy-pra)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (dipy-pra<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane  were prepared and used as self-supported catalysts for the epoxidation of olefins.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Utilization of inorganic-organic hybrid materials and coordination polymers as self-supported catalysts is another development in this regard. Depending on the coordination geometry of the metals and the bonding preference of donating atoms as well as the geometry of organic linkers, coordination polymers with one, two or three dimensions can be constructed. These metal organic assemblies formed via coordinate bonds, hydrogen bonds and aromatic π-π interactions can be insoluble in the conventional reaction media and can be utilized as heterogeneous catalysts. Coordination polymers with extended structures do not suffer from negative effects of some pre-synthesized supports such as random anchoring, reduced catalytic activity and/or selectivity of catalysts due to poor accessibility, or disturbed geometry of active sites in the solid supports . Inorganic-organic hybrids and coordination polymers such as [{CoIICl3}(tptz){CoIICl(H2O)}]⋅0.25H2O (tptz=2,4,6-tris(2-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine),  [Cu(H2btec)(bipy)]∞ (H4btec=1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid) , {[Ni(L)2(H2O)][γ-Mo8O26]⋅0.5 H2O}n (L=1,4-bis (1,2,4-triazol-yi)butane) , and [MoO2Cl2(H2O)2]⋅(H2dipy-pra)Cl2 (dipy-pra=1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane  were prepared and used as self-supported catalysts for the epoxidation of olefins.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">It has been proved that molybdenum complexes are excellent epoxidation catalysts . Therefore, several research groups including us have studied molybdenum oxide-based inorganic–organic hybrid materials, oxomolybdenum complexes as well as polyoxomolybdate compounds .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It has been proved that molybdenum complexes are excellent epoxidation catalysts . Therefore, several research groups including us have studied molybdenum oxide-based inorganic-organic hybrid materials, oxomolybdenum complexes as well as polyoxomolybdate compounds .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">As a part of our continuing interest in oxidation reactions, we report the hydrothermal synthesis, characterization and catalytic behavior of a mixture of blue [CuMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and yellow ([Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>Cl(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>(1,10-phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) crystals in the epoxidation of olefins and allylic alcohols.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As a part of our continuing interest in oxidation reactions, we report the hydrothermal synthesis, characterization and catalytic behavior of a mixture of blue [CuMoO4(N2C12H8)]⋅H2O (1) and yellow ([Cu3 ICl(4,4'-bipy)4][CuII(1,10-phen)2Mo8O26]) (2) crystals in the epoxidation of olefins and allylic alcohols.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st030">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st035">Materials and instrumentation</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">All chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained using a Philips PW1800 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.5406<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the samples were recorded with Bruker Enquinox 55 spectrometer equipped with a single reflection diamond ATR system. The metal content of the sample was measured using inductive coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP) analysis on ICP-OES Optima 8000. Oxidation products were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (HP, Agilent 6890N) equipped with a capillary column (HP-5) and a flame ionization detector (FID). Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) was recorded using a Shimadzu-14A fitted with a capillary column (CBP5-M25).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and instrumentation

All chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained using a Philips PW1800 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5406Å). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the samples were recorded with Bruker Enquinox 55 spectrometer equipped with a single reflection diamond ATR system. The metal content of the sample was measured using inductive coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP) analysis on ICP-OES Optima 8000. Oxidation products were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (HP, Agilent 6890N) equipped with a capillary column (HP-5) and a flame ionization detector (FID). Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) was recorded using a Shimadzu-14A fitted with a capillary column (CBP5-M25).

The starting pH value of the mixture was adjusted to 5.5 by the addition of diluted ethylenediamine solution followed by transferring it to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and keeping it at 165<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days. After slow cooling to room temperature, the resulting product containing 0.162<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g of a mixture of blue (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and yellow ([Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>Cl(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>(1,10-phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]) (4,4′-bipy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-bipyridine and 1,10-phen<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,10-phenanthroline) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)  crystals, was filtered off, washed with distilled water and dried in air.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the catalyst

A mixture of (NH4)6Mo7O24⋅4H2O (0.1mmol, 0.124g), CuCl2⋅2H2O (0.3mmol, 0.052g), 4,4'-bipy (0.3mmol, 0.047g), 1,10-phenanthroline (0.2mmol, 0.036g), KF (0.3mmol, 0.017g) and H2O (10ml) was stirred for 30min in air. The starting pH value of the mixture was adjusted to 5.5 by the addition of diluted ethylenediamine solution followed by transferring it to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and keeping it at 165°C for 4days. After slow cooling to room temperature, the resulting product containing 0.162g of a mixture of blue (1) and yellow ([Cu3 ICl(4,4'-bipy)4][CuII(1,10-phen)2Mo8O26]) (4,4'-bipy=4,4'-bipyridine and 1,10-phen=1,10-phenanthroline) (2)  crystals, was filtered off, washed with distilled water and dried in air.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st045">Catalytic epoxidation process</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">In a typical procedure for the epoxidation reaction, to a mixture of catalyst (100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg) and substrate (8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in chloroform (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml), <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP, 14.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) as oxidant was added. TBHP (70% in H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) was dried prior to use according to the procedure described in the literature . The mixture was refluxed for appropriate time and the final products were quantified with isooctane (8.75<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) as internal standard.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic epoxidation process

In a typical procedure for the epoxidation reaction, to a mixture of catalyst (100mg) and substrate (8mmol) in chloroform (10ml), tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP, 14.4mmol) as oxidant was added. TBHP (70% in H2O) was dried prior to use according to the procedure described in the literature . The mixture was refluxed for appropriate time and the final products were quantified with isooctane (8.75mmol) as internal standard.

The data were deposited in Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, with deposition number CCDC-970134 for 1 and 970133 for 2.

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Structure of [CuMoO4(N2C12H8)]⋅H2O (1)

The crystallographic details for 1 are provided in  . The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of a Cu2+ cation, a molybdate anion, 1,10-phen ligand and one free water molecule ( ). The coordination environment of Cu1 ion exhibits a {CuN2O3} distorted square pyramidal geometry. The Cu1 ion is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms from 1,10-phen (with the bond distances of Cu1-N1=2.038(2)Å and Cu1-N2=2.005(2)Å and bond angles of N1-Cu1-N2=81.67(9)Å), two μ2-O groups at basal position (Cu1-O1=1.927(2)Å; Cu1-O3=1.906(2)Å) and one μ2-O group at apical position (Cu1-O2=2.269(2)Å). Each Mo1 site has a distorted tetrahedral geometry and is surrounded by three μ2-O atoms (Mo1-O2=1.756(2)Å; Mo1-O3=1.763(2)Å; Mo1-O1=1.773(2)Å) and one terminal Ot atom (Mo1-O4=1.726(2)Å). The bond lengths and angles are in agreement with those reported for other copper molybdate coordination polymers ( ) .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st070">Catalytic epoxidation of olefins and allylic alcohols in the presence of [CuMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and ([Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>Cl(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>(1,10-phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">The prepared crystals were tested as catalyst in the liquid-phase epoxidation of some olefins and allylic alcohols using TBHP as oxidant. As seen in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0015"></ce:float-anchor>, the prepared catalyst can act as active and selective catalyst in the epoxidation of the selected olefins and allylic alcohols. 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol as a representative substrate was chosen for the early exploration of the reaction conditions. The obtained results for the catalytic epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol with TBHP within various reaction times are presented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>. It is evident that the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol proceeds rapidly in the first 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min with the conversion of 85%, but then it continues more slowly until it is mostly oxidized within 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h beyond which no considerable oxidation occurs. Blank experiment performed in the absence of the catalyst gave low conversion (28%) after 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h under the same conditions. In order to provide a better insight into the catalytic activity of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the crystals of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were prepared according to the procedure described in the literature  and utilized as heterogeneous catalyst for the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol. The results (shown in ) revealed that the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol in the presence of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> proceeds slowly within 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic epoxidation of olefins and allylic alcohols in the presence of [CuMoO4(N2C12H8)]⋅H2O (1) and ([Cu3 ICl(4,4'-bipy)4][CuII(1,10-phen)2Mo8O26]) (2)

The prepared crystals were tested as catalyst in the liquid-phase epoxidation of some olefins and allylic alcohols using TBHP as oxidant. As seen in  , the prepared catalyst can act as active and selective catalyst in the epoxidation of the selected olefins and allylic alcohols. 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol as a representative substrate was chosen for the early exploration of the reaction conditions. The obtained results for the catalytic epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol with TBHP within various reaction times are presented in  . It is evident that the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol proceeds rapidly in the first 30min with the conversion of 85%, but then it continues more slowly until it is mostly oxidized within 4h beyond which no considerable oxidation occurs. Blank experiment performed in the absence of the catalyst gave low conversion (28%) after 2h under the same conditions. In order to provide a better insight into the catalytic activity of compound 1, the crystals of compound 2 were prepared according to the procedure described in the literature  and utilized as heterogeneous catalyst for the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol. The results (shown in ) revealed that the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol in the presence of compound 2 proceeds slowly within 3h.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0095" view="all">To investigate the influence of oxidant and solvent on the catalytic epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol, the reaction was carried out with TBHP and CHP in different solvents (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). In all three solvents, higher conversion for the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol was obtained in the presence of TBHP in comparison with CHP. The reason may be that the peroxidic oxygen in TBHP has more electrophilic character. Moreover, the results indicate that 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol exhibits more reactivity in CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and CHCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> rather than CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN. This can be explained with coordination ability of CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN that inhibits the reaction by competing with the oxidant to occupy the coordination sites of the catalyst. These results are consistent with previous reports .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To investigate the influence of oxidant and solvent on the catalytic epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol, the reaction was carried out with TBHP and CHP in different solvents ( ). In all three solvents, higher conversion for the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol was obtained in the presence of TBHP in comparison with CHP. The reason may be that the peroxidic oxygen in TBHP has more electrophilic character. Moreover, the results indicate that 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol exhibits more reactivity in CH2Cl2 and CHCl3 rather than CH3CN. This can be explained with coordination ability of CH3CN that inhibits the reaction by competing with the oxidant to occupy the coordination sites of the catalyst. These results are consistent with previous reports .

<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>. As seen in this Figure, no considerable decrease was observed in the activity of the catalyst within four runs of recycling and reusing.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In order to evaluate the reusability of the catalyst, the epoxidation reaction of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol was performed in the presence of the recovered catalyst and the results are presented in  . As seen in this Figure, no considerable decrease was observed in the activity of the catalyst within four runs of recycling and reusing.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0105" view="all">Powder XRD patterns of the catalyst after and before the reactions are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>. The decreased intensity of the reflections in the recycled sample indicates lower crystallinity of the recycled catalyst. From this Figure, it is clearly seen that there is an acceptable similarity between most of the peaks of simulated XRD patterns from single crystal X-ray data of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and the experimental XRD pattern of the fresh catalyst. The differences in the intensity of the peaks in the simulated and experimental patterns could be due to the preferred orientation of the powder samples during collection of the experimental data.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Powder XRD patterns of the catalyst after and before the reactions are shown in  . The decreased intensity of the reflections in the recycled sample indicates lower crystallinity of the recycled catalyst. From this Figure, it is clearly seen that there is an acceptable similarity between most of the peaks of simulated XRD patterns from single crystal X-ray data of compound 1 and 2 and the experimental XRD pattern of the fresh catalyst. The differences in the intensity of the peaks in the simulated and experimental patterns could be due to the preferred orientation of the powder samples during collection of the experimental data.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0110" view="all">Furthermore, FT-IR spectra (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>) of the recycled and fresh catalyst are quite similar indicating that the structure of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is retained after the catalytic reaction. In the FT-IR spectrum of the fresh catalyst () the peaks appeared in 1570–1415<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> can be assigned to the ligand and the peaks in 660–920<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> are attributed to the Mo<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O and Mo–O–Mo stretching vibrations .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, FT-IR spectra ( ) of the recycled and fresh catalyst are quite similar indicating that the structure of compound 1 is retained after the catalytic reaction. In the FT-IR spectrum of the fresh catalyst () the peaks appeared in 1570-1415cm-1 can be assigned to the ligand and the peaks in 660-920cm-1 are attributed to the MoO and Mo-O-Mo stretching vibrations .

<ce:para id="p0115" view="all">The catalytic activity and stability of the prepared compounds was compared with the other catalysts immobilized on various supports (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0020"></ce:float-anchor>). As seen, the catalytic activity of the prepared self-supported coordination polymer is comparable to the other heterogeneous oxidation catalysts obtained by using different supports such as active carbon (AC), graphene oxide (GO), MOF (UiO-66) and silica coated magnetic nanoparticles (SCMNPs). Moreover, the molybdenum content for the fresh and recycled self-supported catalyst that is determined by ICP-OES analysis is 26.43% and 23.08%, respectively. The recycled catalyst showed little change (about 3%) in the molybdenum content compared to that of fresh catalyst. Similar to the other supported catalysts in , no significant leaching for the molybdenum content was observed after recycling indicating the stability of the catalyst in the epoxidation reaction.</ce:para>

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st075">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0120" view="all">In summary, a mixture of a new 1-D copper molybdate-based coordination polymer and a known metal–organic framework was synthesized through hydrothermal process. The structure of the 1-D coordination polymer was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. The prepared crystals were utilized as heterogeneous catalyst for the epoxidation of some olefins and allylic alcohols. The compounds exhibited good catalytic activity over four successive cycles without significant loss of activity and selectivity.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a mixture of a new 1-D copper molybdate-based coordination polymer and a known metal-organic framework was synthesized through hydrothermal process. The structure of the 1-D coordination polymer was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. The prepared crystals were utilized as heterogeneous catalyst for the epoxidation of some olefins and allylic alcohols. The compounds exhibited good catalytic activity over four successive cycles without significant loss of activity and selectivity.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the catalyst

A mixture of (NH4)6Mo7O24⋅4H2O (0.1mmol, 0.124g), CuCl2⋅2H2O (0.3mmol, 0.052g), 4,4'-bipy (0.3mmol, 0.047g), 1,10-phenanthroline (0.2mmol, 0.036g), KF (0.3mmol, 0.017g) and H2O (10ml) was stirred for 30min in air. The starting pH value of the mixture was adjusted to 5.5 by the addition of diluted ethylenediamine solution followed by transferring it to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and keeping it at 165°C for 4days. After slow cooling to room temperature, the resulting product containing 0.162g of a mixture of blue (1) and yellow ([Cu3 ICl(4,4'-bipy)4][CuII(1,10-phen)2Mo8O26]) (4,4'-bipy=4,4'-bipyridine and 1,10-phen=1,10-phenanthroline) (2)  crystals, was filtered off, washed with distilled water and dried in air.

Catalytic epoxidation process

In a typical procedure for the epoxidation reaction, to a mixture of catalyst (100mg) and substrate (8mmol) in chloroform (10ml), tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP, 14.4mmol) as oxidant was added. TBHP (70% in H2O) was dried prior to use according to the procedure described in the literature . The mixture was refluxed for appropriate time and the final products were quantified with isooctane (8.75mmol) as internal standard.

Catalytic epoxidation of olefins and allylic alcohols in the presence of [CuMoO4(N2C12H8)]⋅H2O (1) and ([Cu3 ICl(4,4'-bipy)4][CuII(1,10-phen)2Mo8O26]) (2)

The prepared crystals were tested as catalyst in the liquid-phase epoxidation of some olefins and allylic alcohols using TBHP as oxidant. As seen in  , the prepared catalyst can act as active and selective catalyst in the epoxidation of the selected olefins and allylic alcohols. 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol as a representative substrate was chosen for the early exploration of the reaction conditions. The obtained results for the catalytic epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol with TBHP within various reaction times are presented in  . It is evident that the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol proceeds rapidly in the first 30min with the conversion of 85%, but then it continues more slowly until it is mostly oxidized within 4h beyond which no considerable oxidation occurs. Blank experiment performed in the absence of the catalyst gave low conversion (28%) after 2h under the same conditions. In order to provide a better insight into the catalytic activity of compound 1, the crystals of compound 2 were prepared according to the procedure described in the literature  and utilized as heterogeneous catalyst for the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol. The results (shown in ) revealed that the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol in the presence of compound 2 proceeds slowly within 3h.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Structure of [CuMoO4(N2C12H8)]⋅H2O (1)

The crystallographic details for 1 are provided in  . The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of a Cu2+ cation, a molybdate anion, 1,10-phen ligand and one free water molecule ( ). The coordination environment of Cu1 ion exhibits a {CuN2O3} distorted square pyramidal geometry. The Cu1 ion is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms from 1,10-phen (with the bond distances of Cu1-N1=2.038(2)Å and Cu1-N2=2.005(2)Å and bond angles of N1-Cu1-N2=81.67(9)Å), two μ2-O groups at basal position (Cu1-O1=1.927(2)Å; Cu1-O3=1.906(2)Å) and one μ2-O group at apical position (Cu1-O2=2.269(2)Å). Each Mo1 site has a distorted tetrahedral geometry and is surrounded by three μ2-O atoms (Mo1-O2=1.756(2)Å; Mo1-O3=1.763(2)Å; Mo1-O1=1.773(2)Å) and one terminal Ot atom (Mo1-O4=1.726(2)Å). The bond lengths and angles are in agreement with those reported for other copper molybdate coordination polymers ( ) .

The infinite one-dimensional chain of 1 along [010] is shown in  . As seen, the structure of 1 consists of copper molybdate coordination polymers in which two units of [CuMoO4] n  are connected to each other through μ2-O atoms to form 8-membered rings of {Cu2Mo2O4}. The rings are joined through Mo1-O3-Cu1 linkages and there are alternatively two kinds of rings in the chains, one with Cu…Cu and Mo…Mo distances of 5.460 (3) and 4.607 (2)Å and the other with the intermetallic distances of 4.961 (1)Å for Mo…Mo and 5.257 (3)Å for Cu…Cu.

The catalytic activity and stability of the prepared compounds was compared with the other catalysts immobilized on various supports ( ). As seen, the catalytic activity of the prepared self-supported coordination polymer is comparable to the other heterogeneous oxidation catalysts obtained by using different supports such as active carbon (AC), graphene oxide (GO), MOF (UiO-66) and silica coated magnetic nanoparticles (SCMNPs). Moreover, the molybdenum content for the fresh and recycled self-supported catalyst that is determined by ICP-OES analysis is 26.43% and 23.08%, respectively. The recycled catalyst showed little change (about 3%) in the molybdenum content compared to that of fresh catalyst. Similar to the other supported catalysts in , no significant leaching for the molybdenum content was observed after recycling indicating the stability of the catalyst in the epoxidation reaction.
